Hi my name is Pravin Srinivasan and my poster is entitled many to one contour matching for describing and discriminating objects shape.
This is joint.
Work with Juju and John Bushey from the Grass Lab at the University of Pennsylvania.
We present a two step method for learning to recognize objects by their shape.

First we learn a descriptive shape model from the positive images are method chooses bottom up image contours from lucky images that contain large clear portions of the object shape instead of simply averaging together, many bad images are method learns from the few clear examples.
Next, we learn a discriminative many to one matching cost function.
For detection that matches many image contours to the Learn shape model, our method uses large scale shape features over the contours that cannot be used in Patch based models.

During learning the many to one matching appears as latent variables, we adapt the latent SVM for learning method of felzenszwalb at all to perform discriminative learning, we evaluate our method on dthe shape categories data set we outperform all previous work including the latent SVM detector of felzenszwalb.
Which shares the same learning framework but uses Patch image features instead of the large scale shape features that we use.
We conclude that large scale shape features discriminative training via latent SVM and learning from lucky images are critical for good detection performance.

Hi, my name is Mochta Prasad and I'm presenting the work Finding Nemo Deformable object class modeling using curve matching.
An image search for an object class such as the clown fish use many different instances of the object class, each of a distinct individual with a different shape in a different pose.

This problem is an extension of existing structure from motion methods, but when each picture is of a different individual, such correspondences are hard to find.
